subject: Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... But the QS inconsistent-spelling-issue is not a problem in practice and does not results in unreadability between accents. True, in theory it seems like it
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Gregory Weidman <delrayva@...>
>
> The thing is: what if he and I were trying to communicate in QS?
> Ifwe wrote QS phonetically, I expect we would completely fail at
> communication. His writing would be as incomprehensible to me as
> his speech. However, with a more regularized spelling,
> written communication between North Carolina and New Zealand
> becomes possible again.
>

But the QS inconsistent-spelling-issue is not a problem in practice
and does not results in unreadability between accents. True, in theory
it seems like it might but in practice virtually all words come out
spelled the same. Those very few that don't will differ only slightly
and can be very easily inferred. To demonstrate this I have just run
the Drake example in the QM though my senior parser and got this result.

http://quickscript.tonygrahn.com/spellcomparison.html

If you compare the two you'll notice they are overwhelmingly the
same spelling. Yet my version uses a dictionary from Carnegie-Melon
university with specific American accent mappings for each QS letter
but the QM example uses RP English (aka BBC or Posh English). So even
though they are virtually identical on the written page, one version
is as it would be written by Queen Elizabeth and the other by David
Hasselhoff!

Most importantly, it was done purely by a machine without any
editing from me so I can't be accused of cooking the results. (please
pardon the extreme ugliness of the image and the occasional odd
connecting of letters, my parser is very much a work in progress.)
